There's two sides to this game: Non-Realistic Mode and Realistic Mode

Non-Realistic Mode scratches the itch for those of you who frothed at the mouth when Cities Skylines: Industries rolled out. It's a really fun game of connecting industry buildings and optimizing logistics while also managing the needs of your citizens. The difficulty doesn't come from cheating the numbers or making your citizens more and more demanding of the same goods, but instead from the complexity of different systems interacting.

Realistic mode is a punishing but rewarding tier of fun where you roleplay an actual city planner with a Comissar watching over you. Your citizens will die. Your first city will burn down because your immigrants missed the bus to the fire station. People will starve because your tractors got stuck in traffic 2 months ago and the food plant had a nightly blackout. 20 hours in, you will have built up perhaps your first housing district.
Communist Factorio but way more difficult. I don't understand how 95% of the game works but its still my favorite. Worth every penny

This has got to be one of the best and most underrated city builders out there. It's $40 regularly, down to $20 on sale sometimes. It is easily worth both prices in my opinion. I am not a super city builder aficionado but I dabble a fair bit. Three main things make this game stand out from other city builders I've played or seen:

The unique premise/setting: it's not a medieval survival city builder where you have 20 residents and get attacked by raiders, it's not a futuristic utopia where food is 3D-printed and jobs are done by robots, and it's not some post-apocalyptic wasteland with a mix of the two. You're a struggling nation in the Soviet bloc in the height of the Cold War. This game isn't flashy, it isn't really cinematic, and it isn't a case of giving some people furniture and they magically elevate from artisan to entrepreneur or whatever and pay 2x the taxes, no, this game is gritty, it's realistic, and in this game, life is hard for your citizens, and it's up to you to help them. The people are the key, most essential resource, and they will work for the greater good of the glorious republic BUT...they are not mindless, nameless sheep and you have to provide for their needs. Foreign attack or invasion isn't a concern because you're under the protection of the Soviet Union, but global events like epidemics and trade fluctuations happen, and can significantly hurt or help you. 

The level of detail: a building with 100 occupants is not a building of 100 workers, it is a building of 100 individuals with different needs, different wants, different routines, different traits, and different thoughts. Unhappy citizens will work slower, and the most unhappy citizens will defect entirely.  Every citizen needs food, which is distributed at the store (needs workers), where it is brought from the factory, after it's been made from crops, which are grown on a farm, which needs the right equipment. Clothing has a similar path as food. Citizens need exercise, for which they prefer sporting facilities, which have to be staffed, but many sporting facilities are outdoor and not useable in the winter/cold weather. Citizens need alcohol, or so they say...they're actually just addicted, and if you give it to them it has to be made and distributed similar to food (with pubs instead of stores). If you don't want to give it to them they will be slightly more unhappy, but healthier ultimately, and they will eventually be free from their alcohol addiction. Citizens need entertainment, in the form of theaters/radio/television. There is a full propaganda system - all citizens have different loyalties to the cause, depending on their individual traits and their prior life experiences (someone who regularly has unmet needs will be less loyal), but the same radio/television can be used as propaganda. There is a full crime system, all citizens have different levels of criminality, the higher criminality the more likely to commit a crime (and more severe). These criminals have to be arrested, tried in court, sentenced depending on the degree of crime, and then put in prison where you dictate how long they will be there and what their rehabilitation program will generally look like. Children of criminals who are imprisoned need to go to an orphanage, otherwise they will grow up in a broken home and they too, will likely become criminals. Citizens need to be educated which affects their usefulness (uneducated workers can't even work, workers with basic education can do some basic jobs, and university level workers can do anything). Workers with young children need kindergartens (daycares) or else they will not be able to work since they need to dedicate their time to childcare instead. Education ties to propaganda, as low loyalty teachers will influence their students accordingly, and same with high loyalty teachers. There is a full day/night weather system, wind affects your wind turbines and their power gen, nighttime (and rain/snow depending on cloud cover) affects your solar plants, snow covers your roads which slows down vehicles until the roads are plowed. There is a full waste system, full building construction system, full water supply system, full power (building power/vehicle fuel) system, full heating system, full traffic system, full tourism system, and more. 

The ability to almost completely customize difficulty: last section, I went over most (probably forgot some) of the detailed and complete systems in the game. It is a lot to manage, and unlike real life where a country would no doubt have a minister/director/secretary of education, energy, justice, etc...it is all you in this game. So the best part is, if you find that the education system is too tedious and want the game to always be day, you can set that. If you want buildings to instantly be built (as opposed to needing to go through the whole construction process) you can enable that. If you want to skip the production chain of food (or anything), you can import it from the border, but at a cost. Really anything can be customized to suit individual playstyles except for basic citizen needs (but even that, you can change how drastically they respond to unmet needs). I, for example, have found the crime system to be a little buggy/confusing and I find needing to provide fuel to every vehicle to be extremely tedious and annoying, so I play with those off now. 

As far as I know, development has largely ended on this game, so don't expect a bunch of major updates in the future, but what is there now is excellent.

An very detailed game if all the settings are turned on, it basically is a full on simulator at that point. There's some headaches in the learning process, I would say it's a harder game to pickup, lots of things are a bit unintuitive and I also miss a good tooltip system.

Compared to other city builders my favourite thing is that you will face very real decisions due to constraints that other games don't offer. Be it financial, time or space constraints. While in other games it's virtually free to fix mistakes or do upgrades, here you might have to complete a full demolish, provide temporary means for your citizens, wait for the construction time and all you wanted was a new substation but you forgot to include a safety switch.

Road upgrades? Can be a nightmare, just like in real life.

One thing I will suggest for new players (or anyone, really) is that don't be hard on yourself and try to be the most efficient/perfect in planning. Just look outside your window, I guarantee your city is full of messes. It's okay to have dingy cities, falling apart infrasturcture and being on the brink of financial ruin. It's all more realistic that way.

I've been playing Factorio, Satisfactory, and Civilization on rotation for a few years now, never expecting to find any other games that might scratch the addictive itch that they can. After some attempts at Transport Fever, Anno, Cities Skylines, and other similar games, I experienced some glimmers of it but not in the way I truly hoped. 

For the first time in years I found a new source of that creative and addicting outlet while playing Workers and Resources. It merges the addicting "just-one-more-turn" style gameplay loop with the problem solving/planning fun of factory games and the creative rewards of a city builder to create a perfect combination of these other titles' offerings. 

The game's systems are deeply complex but fairly intuitive to piece together and scale once you understand their core mechanics. The setting and theme creates a perfect backdrop for the gameplay, making you fall in love with the city and world you're building from scratch. Nothing brings me quite as much joy as seeing my rail distribution office bring supplies from factory storage to a construction office, or seeing open hull trucks haul the pavers and excavators to the roads I just placed for construction. I spend a lot of time in this game just watching my vehicles, trains, and people move around, watching the city live and breathe. I'll just sit and watch my train bring steel to the border, for no reason other than the appreciate the effort of planning, management, construction, and implementation that went into it. The construction aspect alone is one of the most rewarding mechanics I've experienced in gaming, and I encourage anyone to play this game without building anything with rubles. Without construction, a lot of the systems that make this game so enjoyable kind of fall apart and it kind of descends into "Cities Skylines, but you place everything individually". 

The only big issues with this game are really around the learning curve, and a couple of the mechanics being a bit janky. With the former, I felt that the tutorials were split between "place this here, then do this thing, congrats you did it" and "here's a goal, now figure it out", but there wasn't a good sweet spot in between that helped me truly "get" W&R. It took me a few watches of YouTube let's plays and a few hours of upfront investment for things to click. I've found all my favorite games in the past took that similar upfront investment and so I was naturally willing to make it, but I do not blame anyone else for being put off by the sheer complexity. 

With the latter, while so many systems and mechanics work amazingly, there are some weirdly stringent rules you run into with very little context on why they're limiting you. Roads needing to clip into specific nodes or you can't build them at all, conveyors never connecting to anything because of undefined limitations, boats that just drive into the earth and get stuck, oh and the construction trains oh my GOD the construction trains. They ruin your ENTIRE logistics network, and require so much micromanagement. Even after 80 hours and a solid grasp on train signals from similar games, I still am yet to figure out how to build even a single 100m length of track without creating a cascading nightmare of stuck trains. I just find myself having to google issues, and discovering rules and limitations that the game doesn't explicitly communicate. 

With that being said I really really love W&R and am so impressed that such a small dev team made such a intricate and complex game that works as well as it does, especially on their own proprietary engine. I'm so excited to have found that same addicting creative outlet with I did with these other games, and encourage anyone who fans of those other titles to give W&R a try. It can seem intimidating at first but it's so, SO worth it.

Love this game even though it sometimes frustrates me a lot. Wouldn't recommend this game to people that are impatient or want to spend time into learning a game by trial and error.  I haven't seen anything like realistic mode before, which in my opinion makes this game so special. Building a nation starting with nothing, just some dirt roads to lay down and some dirt parking spaces from which construction can be handled feels really satisfying, if... I manage to pull it off.

Can't help but point out some of the negatives, this game shows a great potential of what a city... better said nation builder can look like, that I feel like some things definitely need improvement (though given the old engine, that would probably for a next iteration of this game).
-I've seen way better road traffic in other games, you got two lane roads but it feels like they function as 2 single lane roads next to each other. Apart from early near the customs house, traffic jams are rarely a problem to me, so it is only a small frustration (haven't played with a city with personal cars yet though). Can't thank the creator enough for the new large customs house, major relieve to me, I still don't like that some buildings can have 1 vehicle arrive/leave at the same time.
-Construction Offices kinda automatic select what to build or reconstruct, but they just take so many tasks automatically. So when a critical factory decides to replace machines, it might not get all the necessairy CO's assigned. Sure, you can set them by hand, but:
-Some more customizable warnings would be great. You can select to be informed when a factory stops working, but not because of what reason. So I get annoyed by messages that my waste treatment has no workers all the time, turn the messages of, then don't notice that production stopped because machine replacement is taking place... You can also set stores only to send message when they are empty, way too late if you need to arrange a quick shipment of food to get in (would be great to get a message if the water tower is empty too btw). Still many more messages that come too often, too little or too late, but that's in the end also just quality of life for the players.

That overall makes me often still micromanaging stuff, while it feels intended to be automated. That said, most annoying things are on features I miss entirely in any other game.

What I really love is how the game combines a city planner and a production chain manager. The communist setting might be a bit of a scarecrow to some, but I guess it also adds some "realism", seeing the nation as a giant company/factory where you have to treat your people well as well, but you still control them.
The game can be really punishing, which is kinda what I like. Again it can be daunting especially to new players, but, very important tip: don't go straight to realistic mode at it hardest. And once you do, expect to fail the first few times, because the game thinks about almost everything, which feels like a unique selling point. Once I get my first city/industries/belts running in realistic mode, I felt great joy in it as it felt as a great accomplishment.

I'm a bit mixed about the dlc's. Don't have biomes, feels like that is more about the looks, which I don't care a lot about (still enjoy the scenery, and onboards and how beautiful it looks when everything comes together, but not that important to me). But biomes either remove snow from the map or make it last even longer. Snow is a bit love/hate for me, one season of snow a year is enough for me. I love the aspect of winter, snow plowing and taking care of heat, but it hurts my eyes (so bright) and it becomes really hard to plan and follow construction.
I have the maps DLC, but in the end it is just a bunch of maps (and some extra buildings I believe) while the game has a great random map generator. Also I love the idea of prepopulated maps for the setting, but after a playthrough with dozens of trips at 2% of truck/bus capacity to fix all these small homes with some low quality houses (and more small reasons), I decided to stay away from that (or you can demolish buildings, but then what is the point of a prepopulated map?).
Now Early Start brings some really nice features, but overall makes the game even slower. Right now I play with a mod that slows down time, else I've passed the early start era before I really noticed anything of it. Nice to see the dev listening to the community, but I sometimes feel like the game wasn't made/balanced for it, at least in realistic mode. Overall the game on itself feels really great and the DLC's are a little extra to support the dev and/or get a little extra once you got some more hours in the game.

Overall I think it's a great game that pushes the limits of city/nation builders, but also has it limitations that can be frustrating, but still beats anything I've seen out there.

An excellent city builder and also great for people who love logistics games.  It has complex production chains needing you to not only transport and refine or use resources along the way, but account for the, as the game suggests, workers and resources to keep those chains moving.  Workers need to be transported to work, and done so somewhat efficiently - if they spend too long travelling they'll work a shorter shift.  Resources need to be moved too of course.  You need to maintain and have the resources for that transportation.  Even the simplest answer of trucks and busses still means bulldozers and dumptrucks to lay even just gravel roads, then fuel for those vehicles, and resources at repair depots to maintain them over their lifespan.  These fuel and maintenance requirements aren't simple running costs that deduct money every so often - they have to go get gas or get to a maintenance yard.  This means even these logistics needs thought put into their placement.

Your workers also have to be managed and satisfied.  You cannot simply set some high wage at a job to produce magical satisfaction.  In fact, money is only used to trade with other countries.  A satisfied worker is a happy and productive worker.  Of course they need a place to live, which already comes with setting up a water, sewer, and power grid.  They need to be healthy, meaning clinics and hospitals but also trash service and residences built far enough away from heavy industry's pollution and smog.  Of course they need food, which means a store for them to collect it from and/or restaurants to eat at.  They demand access to arts, culture, and athletics, so you need gyms, football fields, museums, cinemas, etc.  All of these need workers too.  To get workers you can use money to hire temporary ones or pay costs to import workers or specialists, but primarily you need people happy and healthy enough to have and raise children.  If you don't provide early childcare facilities at least one parent will stay home to raise the child.  To do any job workers require a basic education, meaning schools.  If you want your society to thrive at all you will also need a university to train specialists - teachers, doctors, judges, nuclear technicians, etc.

From the very beginning — bugs and all — it’s obvious this game is a true labour of love, and a testament to how developers should approach their craft.

What sets it apart from titles like Cities: Skylines is simple: you don’t just design infrastructure… you have to build it. Roads, water networks, factories, rail — every project requires planning, manpower, materials, and actual construction. That single design philosophy transforms the entire experience. Suddenly, infrastructure isn’t just a cosmetic layer. It’s functional, logistical, and genuinely challenging.

And yes, sometimes you’ll upgrade a pipe network and half your town will panic or even die off — but that’s the beauty of it. The systems are deep, interconnected, and unforgiving in the best way. You feel the consequences of your decisions, and the satisfaction when everything finally works is unmatched.

The economic simulation, the political flavour, the detailed population behaviour — it all comes together into something special. It’s not just a city builder; it’s an industrial, economic, and societal simulator with an incredible amount of depth.

If you enjoy complex strategy, meaningful logistics, and games that reward thoughtful planning, Workers & Resources is genuinely in a league of its own.

One of the best city builider/logisitic sims/resource management games I've ever played.

I've played a lot of Cities:Skylines, OpenTTD, Railroad Tycoon and Factorio, and they've all given me hundreds of hours of entertainment, but this sits somewhere between all of them and scratches an itch I didn't previously know was there.

The cities don't look as pretty as in Cities:Skylines, but its Soviet, gritty aesthetic just works and means your computer isn't heating the room to 80 degrees to make it look good.

The trains don't run with the efficiency you can achieve in OpenTTD, but it doesn't matter, because after 8 hours of tweaking and correcting mistakes, you've finally hooked up the coal mines to the steel mill, with workers brought in and a functioning waste removal service on a somewhat clogged up rail line; and it's beautiful.

You won't have the OCD compliant production chains of Factorio; you WILL have janky cargo connections where they fit, you will have sheer drops between buildings from the terraforming, you will do just about anything to avoid having to keep a new building inside of an existing power connection's range, you will have paths that weave in and out of the buildings clustered around a bus station to ensure they're reachable.

This game doesn't necessarily do any of these individual things as well as any other single game, but it does it ALL simultaneously and combines it into the most challenging and satisfying econ-based game ever.

DO make sure you start out on easy. Give yourself loads of cash, replace your population as they inevitably die off, and slowly add elements (e.g. water, pollution, energy - be wary of education, waste and police as they can get very challenging to manage when starting out)

The learning curve is challenging (imagine a 45 degree line, but just going on indefinitely - it's not the steepest, but it really does just keep going!) and does require some persistence to really get the most out of the game.

...Comrades, forgive me but while I genuinely enjoy this game a lot, it just caused me so much frustration I simply feel the need to leave a negative review...

Positives: 
- Graphics are fantastic
- Sound design feels really good
- Management ideas are amazing along with the production lines automation systems and import-export mechanics.
- With the steam workshop it has support for assets of all sorts, giving the player even more freedom of choice
- The general idea of the game is fantastic, however my problem is with the execution

Which brings me to the negatives.... where do I even begin.
- Building and road placement: it's as precise as trying to do heart surgery with a shovel. it just doesn't work and there is no grid or anything for precise building placement, only for rotation while holding ctrl. Often the game will have you make a workaround to build things the way you want... let me explain: Let's say I want to build a house next to a road that also has a power line running alongside it into an already closed grid. It will not let me place the building. However if I first delete the power line, then build the house, and then put the power lines back to where they were, then it lets me... god please help my nerves, the amount of times this has happened... and there is more examples to this but the review is already too long as is.
The roads can't do a 90 degree bend from the end of a node, only away from the end. You cannot have a node have both a pedestrian and a road crossing. On top of all of this instead of having road types and being able to have them have bridge/elevated/tunnel versions, you need to select a different menu point for tunnel, bridge and elevated roads instead of having a simple sub-menu as you are building the roads. Overall feels very restrictive with what you can build and is very cumbersome. Also all of the building's technical size is larger than they appear, and it won't allow you to place buildings anywhere near eachother, or next to a road. This completely killed all of my attempts at detailing or optimalising layouts. (not to mention you cannot move buildings after placing them and if you want to build on uneven ground you have to first manually flatten the ground and only then you can place the building). 
- The UI: it's just not intuitive at all, even after 10 hours of gameplay I have to keep looking for certain buildings for a solid minute before finding which menu point they hid it under. Here I would have to add that you cannot make a bridge or elevated road/railway have intersections and therefore it can only have one connection on each end, which is still fine with car and pedestrian roads, but for trains you just have to build 2 separate bridges or make a loop-connection for the rails on each end if you want the trains to be able to go both ways. placing even pedestrian bridges/tunnels is also really cumbersome, because it only allows a certain bend, and anything beyond that is forbidden. placing pipes and other underground connections are also very restrictive because it needs "a proper slope". You just always need to find some sort of workaround to actually have the pipes connect unless you are building it on relatively flat ground.
- Don't even know where to list this: while there is a religion mechanic in the game, there are no religious buildings in the base game to fulfil the religious needs of your people, only with mods or built in the pre-built towns around the map.
- logistics: by default I think the logistics are in order and I love managing the connections between factories and warehouses, managing imports and exports. But the worst offense in my eyes is that while you can tell your trucks to load certain percentages of the weight they can carry of a certain product, if the destination building gets full, and it cannot unload all of that product, the whole truck is just going to fill up with one product in the end, making it virtually impossible to manage having one truck delivering several products unless it's for exports. If I set it to 50% it shouldn't allow the truck to pick up more than 50% of its maximum load at all. So because of this, manually setting up trucks is barely an option if it's for more than one type of product. Instead you have to get a separate truck for every product, and then you can have them deliver that single product to several destinations. You can then automate it by building distribution offices that will deliver missing products to all buildings automatically once set up correctly but at first you have to complete a research for that. Also I don't know if this is a bug or not, but when setting up the truck to take something like nuclear fuel or nuclear waste, there is a general menu for that in the logistics menu, but if you specify what to pick up, it just won't. somehow specifying the exact thing just won't have the truck pick up those items unless you just select the whole menu point. you can even go into the menu and select every single resource/vehicle under it, but it still won't pick up anything until you untick every single one of them.
- Utilities: again, just feels incredibly cumbersome. Having to build a source, then the whole network consists of 2-3 pieces... which would be fine, but the range feels small, and sometimes you need to build several of them because just one of them would get too many connections or not have enough capacity to provide for all the buildings around it. In the end especially with all the power lines necessary (because you need to connect every single one of them to a power substation manually through power lines) it feels like an absolute mess and increasingly more difficult to make the build actually look nice.
- Worker movement and worker counts: buses and trains are very nice, they carry passengers here and there, however just because you have a train connection to a semi-distant building still doesn't mean people are going to work there. I had buildings that were just standing empty despite having public transport connections to them, and they only got workers once I built a house within 400m's of the building. and I must add that after 10 hours I still don't understand the benefits of having public transport and cars available to people if it doesn't noticeably extend the range in which people can move around.
- Weak introduction and tutorials: There is a campaign and some tutorials that are supposed to introduce you to the game and try to ease you into it, however there are still a lot of things it doesn't explain to you very well. And while often it tells you what to do, it doesn't always tell you how to do it. I think the below 10% achievement for completing the first campaign says it all. People like to be eased into the game they chose to play and it should be helping people to understand the the mechanics, because there will be people who might play this as their first game of this genre and will completely abandon it after a few hours of trying.

...Comrades, forgive me but while I genuinely enjoy this game a lot, it just caused me so much frustration I simply feel the need to leave a negative review...

Positives: 
- Graphics are fantastic
- Sound design feels really good
- Management ideas are amazing along with the production lines automation systems and import-export mechanics.
- With the steam workshop it has support for assets of all sorts, giving the player even more freedom of choice
- The general idea of the game is fantastic, however my problem is with the execution

Which brings me to the negatives.... where do I even begin.
- Building and road placement: it's as precise as trying to do heart surgery with a shovel. it just doesn't work and there is no grid or anything for precise building placement, only for rotation while holding ctrl. Often the game will have you make a workaround to build things the way you want... let me explain: Let's say I want to build a house next to a road that also has a power line running alongside it into an already closed grid. It will not let me place the building. However if I first delete the power line, then build the house, and then put the power lines back to where they were, then it lets me... god please help my nerves, the amount of times this has happened... and there is more examples to this but the review is already too long as is.
The roads can't do a 90 degree bend from the end of a node, only away from the end. You cannot have a node have both a pedestrian and a road crossing. On top of all of this instead of having road types and being able to have them have bridge/elevated/tunnel versions, you need to select a different menu point for tunnel, bridge and elevated roads instead of having a simple sub-menu as you are building the roads. Overall feels very restrictive with what you can build and is very cumbersome. Also all of the building's technical size is larger than they appear, and it won't allow you to place buildings anywhere near eachother, or next to a road. This completely killed all of my attempts at detailing or optimalising layouts. (not to mention you cannot move buildings after placing them and if you want to build on uneven ground you have to first manually flatten the ground and only then you can place the building). 
- The UI: it's just not intuitive at all, even after 10 hours of gameplay I have to keep looking for certain buildings for a solid minute before finding which menu point they hid it under. Here I would have to add that you cannot make a bridge or elevated road/railway have intersections and therefore it can only have one connection on each end, which is still fine with car and pedestrian roads, but for trains you just have to build 2 separate bridges or make a loop-connection for the rails on each end if you want the trains to be able to go both ways. placing even pedestrian bridges/tunnels is also really cumbersome, because it only allows a certain bend, and anything beyond that is forbidden. placing pipes and other underground connections are also very restrictive because it needs "a proper slope". You just always need to find some sort of workaround to actually have the pipes connect unless you are building it on relatively flat ground.
- Don't even know where to list this: while there is a religion mechanic in the game, there are no religious buildings in the base game to fulfil the religious needs of your people, only with mods or built in the pre-built towns around the map.
- logistics: by default I think the logistics are in order and I love managing the connections between factories and warehouses, managing imports and exports. But the worst offense in my eyes is that while you can tell your trucks to load certain percentages of the weight they can carry of a certain product, if the destination building gets full, and it cannot unload all of that product, the whole truck is just going to fill up with one product in the end, making it virtually impossible to manage having one truck delivering several products unless it's for exports. If I set it to 50% it shouldn't allow the truck to pick up more than 50% of its maximum load at all. So because of this, manually setting up trucks is barely an option if it's for more than one type of product. Instead you have to get a separate truck for every product, and then you can have them deliver that single product to several destinations. You can then automate it by building distribution offices that will deliver missing products to all buildings automatically once set up correctly but at first you have to complete a research for that. Also I don't know if this is a bug or not, but when setting up the truck to take something like nuclear fuel or nuclear waste, there is a general menu for that in the logistics menu, but if you specify what to pick up, it just won't. somehow specifying the exact thing just won't have the truck pick up those items unless you just select the whole menu point. you can even go into the menu and select every single resource/vehicle under it, but it still won't pick up anything until you untick every single one of them.
- Utilities: again, just feels incredibly cumbersome. Having to build a source, then the whole network consists of 2-3 pieces... which would be fine, but the range feels small, and sometimes you need to build several of them because just one of them would get too many connections or not have enough capacity to provide for all the buildings around it. In the end especially with all the power lines necessary (because you need to connect every single one of them to a power substation manually through power lines) it feels like an absolute mess and increasingly more difficult to make the build actually look nice.
- Worker movement and worker counts: buses and trains are very nice, they carry passengers here and there, however just because you have a train connection to a semi-distant building still doesn't mean people are going to work there. I had buildings that were just standing empty despite having public transport connections to them, and they only got workers once I built a house within 400m's of the building. and I must add that after 10 hours I still don't understand the benefits of having public transport and cars available to people if it doesn't noticeably extend the range in which people can move around.
- Weak introduction and tutorials: There is a campaign and some tutorials that are supposed to introduce you to the game and try to ease you into it, however there are still a lot of things it doesn't explain to you very well. And while often it tells you what to do, it doesn't always tell you how to do it. I think the below 10% achievement for completing the first campaign says it all. People like to be eased into the game they chose to play and it should be helping people to understand the the mechanics, because there will be people who might play this as their first game of this genre and will completely abandon it after a few hours of trying.

But on the other hand it feels very unpolished, and does very little effort to help new players get into it, which has brought me a lot of frustration even after playing other strategy/management/city builder games for thousands of hours and having plenty of experience with similar games. ...Comrades, forgive me but while I genuinely enjoy this game a lot, it just caused me so much frustration I simply feel the need to leave a negative review...

Positives: 
- Graphics are fantastic
- Sound design feels really good
- Management ideas are amazing along with the production lines automation systems and import-export mechanics.
- With the steam workshop it has support for assets of all sorts, giving the player even more freedom of choice
- The general idea of the game is fantastic, however my problem is with the execution

Which brings me to the negatives.... where do I even begin.
- Building and road placement: it's as precise as trying to do heart surgery with a shovel. it just doesn't work and there is no grid or anything for precise building placement, only for rotation while holding ctrl. Often the game will have you make a workaround to build things the way you want... let me explain: Let's say I want to build a house next to a road that also has a power line running alongside it into an already closed grid. It will not let me place the building. However if I first delete the power line, then build the house, and then put the power lines back to where they were, then it lets me... god please help my nerves, the amount of times this has happened... and there is more examples to this but the review is already too long as is.
The roads can't do a 90 degree bend from the end of a node, only away from the end. You cannot have a node have both a pedestrian and a road crossing. On top of all of this instead of having road types and being able to have them have bridge/elevated/tunnel versions, you need to select a different menu point for tunnel, bridge and elevated roads instead of having a simple sub-menu as you are building the roads. Overall feels very restrictive with what you can build and is very cumbersome. Also all of the building's technical size is larger than they appear, and it won't allow you to place buildings anywhere near eachother, or next to a road. This completely killed all of my attempts at detailing or optimalising layouts. (not to mention you cannot move buildings after placing them and if you want to build on uneven ground you have to first manually flatten the ground and only then you can place the building). 
- The UI: it's just not intuitive at all, even after 10 hours of gameplay I have to keep looking for certain buildings for a solid minute before finding which menu point they hid it under. Here I would have to add that you cannot make a bridge or elevated road/railway have intersections and therefore it can only have one connection on each end, which is still fine with car and pedestrian roads, but for trains you just have to build 2 separate bridges or make a loop-connection for the rails on each end if you want the trains to be able to go both ways. placing even pedestrian bridges/tunnels is also really cumbersome, because it only allows a certain bend, and anything beyond that is forbidden. placing pipes and other underground connections are also very restrictive because it needs "a proper slope". You just always need to find some sort of workaround to actually have the pipes connect unless you are building it on relatively flat ground.
- Don't even know where to list this: while there is a religion mechanic in the game, there are no religious buildings in the base game to fulfil the religious needs of your people, only with mods or built in the pre-built towns around the map.
- logistics: by default I think the logistics are in order and I love managing the connections between factories and warehouses, managing imports and exports. But the worst offense in my eyes is that while you can tell your trucks to load certain percentages of the weight they can carry of a certain product, if the destination building gets full, and it cannot unload all of that product, the whole truck is just going to fill up with one product in the end, making it virtually impossible to manage having one truck delivering several products unless it's for exports. If I set it to 50% it shouldn't allow the truck to pick up more than 50% of its maximum load at all. So because of this, manually setting up trucks is barely an option if it's for more than one type of product. Instead you have to get a separate truck for every product, and then you can have them deliver that single product to several destinations. You can then automate it by building distribution offices that will deliver missing products to all buildings automatically once set up correctly but at first you have to complete a research for that. Also I don't know if this is a bug or not, but when setting up the truck to take something like nuclear fuel or nuclear waste, there is a general menu for that in the logistics menu, but if you specify what to pick up, it just won't. somehow specifying the exact thing just won't have the truck pick up those items unless you just select the whole menu point. you can even go into the menu and select every single resource/vehicle under it, but it still won't pick up anything until you untick every single one of them.
- Utilities: again, just feels incredibly cumbersome. Having to build a source, then the whole network consists of 2-3 pieces... which would be fine, but the range feels small, and sometimes you need to build several of them because just one of them would get too many connections or not have enough capacity to provide for all the buildings around it. In the end especially with all the power lines necessary (because you need to connect every single one of them to a power substation manually through power lines) it feels like an absolute mess and increasingly more difficult to make the build actually look nice.
- Worker movement and worker counts: buses and trains are very nice, they carry passengers here and there, however just because you have a train connection to a semi-distant building still doesn't mean people are going to work there. I had buildings that were just standing empty despite having public transport connections to them, and they only got workers once I built a house within 400m's of the building. and I must add that after 10 hours I still don't understand the benefits of having public transport and cars available to people if it doesn't noticeably extend the range in which people can move around.
- Weak introduction and tutorials: There is a campaign and some tutorials that are supposed to introduce you to the game and try to ease you into it, however there are still a lot of things it doesn't explain to you very well. And while often it tells you what to do, it doesn't always tell you how to do it. I think the below 10% achievement for completing the first campaign says it all. People like to be eased into the game they chose to play and it should be helping people to understand the the mechanics, because there will be people who might play this as their first game of this genre and will completely abandon it after a few hours of trying.

TL;DR: it has a very enjoyable gameplay with the management of resources and the logistics and despite the negative review I will keep playing it for a while because I must say, despite all the negatives it's still a very fun game. But on the other hand it feels very unpolished, and does very little effort to help new players get into it, which has brought me a lot of frustration even after playing other strategy/management/city builder games for thousands of hours and having plenty of experience with similar games. Generally to me it feels like the difficulty of the game comes from a lot of things being really cumbersome and slow rather than being actually difficult.
